name: Transform SOP
description: The Transform SOP translates, rotates and scales the input geometry in "object space" or local to the SOP. The Model Editor and the Transform SOP both work in "object space", and change the X Y Z positions of the points. In contrast, animating the transformation channels of an object in the Geometry Viewer Pane moves/scales the entire object in "world space" and does not affect the XYZ point positions of the geometry.
summary: The Transform SOP translates, rotates and scales the input geometry in "object space" or local to the SOP. The Model Editor and the Transform SOP both work in "object space", and change the X Y Z posi

parameters.name: Group
parameters.label: Group
parameters.description:
From Derivative
		
		
		
		
		Jump to navigation
		Jump to search
		
The Transform  translates, rotates and scales the input geometry in "object space" or local to the . The Model Editor and the Transform  both work in "object space", and change the X Y Z positions of the points. In contrast, animating the transformation channels of an object in the  Pane moves/scales the entire object in "world space" and does not affect the XYZ point positions of the geometry.
transformSOP_Class

Contents
 
 
 
 
 
 
 





  group - If there are input groups, specifying a group name in this field will cause this  to act only upon the group specified. Accepts patterns, as described in Pattern Matching.



  xord -  - Sets the overall transform order for the transformations. The transform order determines the order in which transformations take place. Depending on the order, you can achieve different results using the exact same values. Choose the appropriate order from the menu.

 srt - str - rst - rts - tsr - trs -

  rord -  - Sets the order of the rotations within the overall transform order.

 xyz - xzy - yxz - yzx - zxy - zyx -

  t -  - These three fields move the Source geometry in the three axes.

 tx - ty - tz -

  r -  - These three fields rotate the Source geometry in the three axes.

 rx - ry - rz -

  s -  - These three fields scale the Source geometry in the three axes.

 sx - sy - sz -

  p -  - The pivot point for the transformations (not the same as the pivot point in the pivot channels). The pivot point parameters allow you to define the point about which geometry scales and rotates. Altering the pivot point produces different results depending on the transformation performed on the object.	
For example, during a scaling operation, if the pivot point of an object is located at: -1, -1, 0 and you wanted to scale the object by 0.5 (reduce its size by 50%) the object would scale toward the pivot point and appear to slide down and to the left.			
			
In the example above, rotations performed on an object with different pivot points produce very different results.


 px - py - pz -

  scale -  allows you to shrink or enlarge geometry along all three axes simultaneously.



  vlength - When selected, vector type attributes (i.e. normals, velocity) maintain the same length under transforms. i.e. When geometry is scaled, the normals remain constant in length.



  lookat - Allows you to orient your object by naming the object you would like it to , or point to. Once you have designated this object to look at, it will continue to face that object, even if you move it. This is useful if, for instance, you want a camera to follow another object's movements. The  parameter points the object in question at the other object's origin.	
Tip: To designate a centre of interest for the camera that doesn't appear in your scene, create a Null object and disable its display flag. Then Parent the Camera to the newly created Null object, and tell the camera to look at this object using the  parameter. You can direct the attention of the camera by moving the Null object with the Select state. If you want to see both the camera and the Null object, enable the Null object's display flag, and use the Select state in an additional Viewport by clicking one of the icons in the top-right corner of the TouchDesigner window.



  upvector -  - When orienting an object, the  is used to determine where the positive Y axis points.

 upvectorx - upvectory - upvectorz -

  forwarddir -  - 

 posx - negx - posy - negy - posz - negz -



The transforms on this page are apllied after the settings made on the Transform page (see above).

  postxord -  - Set the order in which scale and transform is applied in the post transform.

 st - ts -

  posttx -  - Sets the center of the geometry after the Transform page has been applied.

 off - No Change. origin - Moves the geometry to the origin 0,0,0. reference - Moves the geometry to a location based on the  Input supplied to this 's second input (ie. Input 1).

  fromx -  - Determines which part of the input geometry to align to the Origin or  Input as selected in Post Translate parameter above.

 min - Align to the geometry's minimum bounds in this axis. center - Align to the geometry's center point in this axis. max - Align to the geometry's maximum bounds in this axis.

  tox -  - When using  Input this determines which part of the  Input to align the geometry to.

 min - Align to the  Input's minimum bounds in this axis. center - Align to the  Input's center in this axis. max - Align to the  Input's maximum bounds in this axis.

  postty -  - Sets the center of the geometry after the Transform page has been applied.

 off - No Change. origin - Moves the geometry to the origin 0,0,0. reference - Moves the geometry to a location based on the  Input supplied to this 's second input (ie. Input 1).

  fromy -  - Determines which part of the input geometry to align to the Origin or  Input as selected in Post Translate parameter above.

 min - Align to the geometry's minimum bounds in this axis. center - Align to the geometry's center point in this axis. max - Align to the geometry's maximum bounds in this axis.

  toy -  - When using  Input this determines which part of the  Input to align the geometry to.

 min - Align to the  Input's minimum bounds in this axis. center - Align to the  Input's center in this axis. max - Align to the  Input's maximum bounds in this axis.

  posttz -  - Sets the center of the geometry after the Transform page has been applied.

 off - No Change. origin - Moves the geometry to the origin 0,0,0. reference - Moves the geometry to a location based on the  Input supplied to this 's second input (ie. Input 1).

  fromz -  - Determines which part of the input geometry to align to the Origin or  Input as selected in Post Translate parameter above.

 min - Align to the geometry's minimum bounds in this axis. center - Align to the geometry's center point in this axis. max - Align to the geometry's maximum bounds in this axis.

  toz -  - When using  Input this determines which part of the  Input to align the geometry to.

 min - Align to the  Input's minimum bounds in this axis. center - Align to the  Input's center in this axis. max - Align to the  Input's maximum bounds in this axis.

  postscale -  - Sets the scale of the geometry after the Transform page has been applied.

 peraxis - Allows individual settings for each axis using the parameters below. unity - Scales the geometry to fit in a 1,1,1 bounding box. reference - Scales the geometry to fit the  Input's bounding box (second input on this  ie. Input 1).

  postscalex -  - Sets the scale of the geometry after the Transform page has been applied to scale.

 off - No change the the scale in this axis. unity - Scale the geometry to 1.0 (ie. -0.5 to 0.5) in this axis. reference - Scale the geometry to fit the  Input in this axis. unityprop - Scale the geometry to 1.0 (ie. -0.5 to 0.5) in this axis while keeping the input geometry's original proportions. referenceprop - Scale the geometry to fit the  Input in this axis while keeping the input geometry's original proportions.

  postscaley -  - Sets the scale of the geometry after the Transform page has been applied to scale.

 off - No change the the scale in this axis. unity - Scale the geometry to 1.0 (ie. -0.5 to 0.5) in this axis. reference - Scale the geometry to fit the  Input in this axis. unityprop - Scale the geometry to 1.0 (ie. -0.5 to 0.5) in this axis while keeping the input geometry's original proportions. referenceprop - Scale the geometry to fit the  Input in this axis while keeping the input geometry's original proportions.

  postscalez -  - Sets the scale of the geometry after the Transform page has been applied to scale.

 off - No change the the scale in this axis. unity - Scale the geometry to 1.0 (ie. -0.5 to 0.5) in this axis. reference - Scale the geometry to fit the  Input in this axis. unityprop - Scale the geometry to 1.0 (ie. -0.5 to 0.5) in this axis while keeping the input geometry's original proportions. referenceprop - Scale the geometry to fit the  Input in this axis while keeping the input geometry's original proportions.



 -
 -

Extra Information for the Transform  can be accessed via an Info CHOP.



 - Number of points in this . - Number of primitives in this . - Number of particles in this . - Time spent in another thread updating geometry data on the  from the 's CPU data. As it is part of another thread, this time is not part of the usual frame time. - Time spent in another thread updating meta surface geometry data (such as metaballs or nurbs) on the  from the 's CPU data. As it is part of another thread, this time is not part of the usual frame time.
 - Number of times the operator has cooked since the process started. - Duration of the last cook in milliseconds. - Frame number when this operator was last cooked relative to the component timeline. - Frame number when this operator was last cooked relative to the absolute time. - Time in milliseconds at which the operator started cooking in the frame it was cooked. - Time in milliseconds at which the operator finished cooking in the frame it was cooked. - 1 if operator was cooked this frame. - Number of warnings in this operator if any. - Number of errors in this operator if any.
TouchDesigner Build: Latest\nwikieditorwikieditorwikieditor2021.100002018.28070before 2018.28070
SOPs
• • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • 

A Operator Family that reads, creates and modifies 3D points, polygons, lines, particles, surfaces, spheres and meatballs. Particles and point clouds are now done primarily on the GPU using TOPs.



A 3D viewport for viewing and manipulating 3D scenes or objects interactively. A geometry viewer can be found in Panes (alt+3 in any pane) or the Node Viewers of all Geometry Object components.



A Link. The grey dashed lines between nodes is a Reference or Link that indicates one operator is getting data from another operator from any Operator Family.


The grey dashed lines between nodes is a Reference (or Link). A Reference is (1) a Parameter Reference, a parameter in an OP that is a name or path to another operator, (2) a Node Reference, an expression in a parameter or DAT script that contains the name or path of another operator, (3) a DAT Cell Reference or (4) a CHOP Channel Reference.


A Link or Reference is a dashed line between nodes that represent other data flowing between nodes. Examples are CHOP Exports, node Paths in parameters, and expressions in parameters referencing CHOP channels, DAT tables and other nodes. In contrast is a Wire that connects nodes in the same Operator Family.



An Operator Family which operate on Channels (a sequence of numbers (Samples)) which are used for animation, audio, mathematics, simulation, logic, UI construction, and data streamed from/to devices and protocols.



The Graphics Processing Unit. This is the high-speed, many-core processor of the graphics card/chip that takes geometry, images and data from the CPU and creates images and processed data.








Retrieved from "https://docs.derivative.ca/index.php?title=Transform_SOP&oldid=29944"
		Category: SOPs

 off - No change the the scale in this axis. unity - Scale the geometry to 1.0 (ie. -0.5 to 0.5) in this axis. reference - Scale the geometry to fit the  Input in this axis. unityprop - Scale the geometry to 1.0 (ie. -0.5 to 0.5) in this axis while keeping the input geometry's original proportions. referenceprop - Scale the geometry to fit the  Input in this axis while keeping the input geometry's original proportions.

  postscaley -  - Sets the scale of the geometry after the Transform page has been applied to scale.

 off - No change the the scale in this axis. unity - Scale the geometry to 1.0 (ie. -0.5 to 0.5) in this axis. reference - Scale the geometry to fit the  Input in this axis. unityprop - Scale the geometry to 1.0 (ie. -0.5 to 0.5) in this axis while keeping the input geometry's original proportions. referenceprop - Scale the geometry to fit the  Input in this axis while keeping the input geometry's original proportions.

  postscalez -  - Sets the scale of the geometry after the Transform page has been applied to scale.

 off - No change the the scale in this axis. unity - Scale the geometry to 1.0 (ie. -0.5 to 0.5) in this axis. reference - Scale the geometry to fit the  Input in this axis. unityprop - Scale the geometry to 1.0 (ie. -0.5 to 0.5) in this axis while keeping the input geometry's original proportions. referenceprop - Scale the geometry to fit the  Input in this axis while keeping the input geometry's original proportions.



 -
 -

Extra Information for the Transform  can be accessed via an Info CHOP.



 - Number of points in this . - Number of primitives in this . - Number of particles in this . - Time spent in another thread updating geometry data on the  from the 's CPU data. As it is part of another thread, this time is not part of the usual frame time. - Time spent in another thread updating meta surface geometry data (such as metaballs or nurbs) on the  from the 's CPU data. As it is part of another thread, this time is not part of the usual frame time.
 - Number of times the operator has cooked since the process started. - Duration of the last cook in milliseconds. - Frame number when this operator was last cooked relative to the component timeline. - Frame number when this operator was last cooked relative to the absolute time. - Time in milliseconds at which the operator started cooking in the frame it was cooked. - Time in milliseconds at which the operator finished cooking in the frame it was cooked. - 1 if operator was cooked this frame. - Number of warnings in this operator if any. - Number of errors in this operator if any.

SOPs
• • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • 

A Operator Family that reads, creates and modifies 3D points, polygons, lines, particles, surfaces, spheres and meatballs. Particles and point clouds are now done primarily on the GPU using TOPs.



A 3D viewport for viewing and manipulating 3D scenes or objects interactively. A geometry viewer can be found in Panes (alt+3 in any pane) or the Node Viewers of all Geometry Object components.



A Link. The grey dashed lines between nodes is a Reference or Link that indicates one operator is getting data from another operator from any Operator Family.


The grey dashed lines between nodes is a Reference (or Link). A Reference is (1) a Parameter Reference, a parameter in an OP that is a name or path to another operator, (2) a Node Reference, an expression in a parameter or DAT script that contains the name or path of another operator, (3) a DAT Cell Reference or (4) a CHOP Channel Reference.


A Link or Reference is a dashed line between nodes that represent other data flowing between nodes. Examples are CHOP Exports, node Paths in parameters, and expressions in parameters referencing CHOP channels, DAT tables and other nodes. In contrast is a Wire that connects nodes in the same Operator Family.



An Operator Family which operate on Channels (a sequence of numbers (Samples)) which are used for animation, audio, mathematics, simulation, logic, UI construction, and data streamed from/to devices and protocols.



The Graphics Processing Unit. This is the high-speed, many-core processor of the graphics card/chip that takes geometry, images and data from the CPU and creates images and processed data.








Retrieved from "https://docs.derivative.ca/index.php?title=Transform_SOP&oldid=29944"

parameters.name: Group
parameters.label: Group
parameters.description: group - If there are input groups, specifying a group name in this field will cause this  to act only upon the group specified. Accepts patterns, as described in Pattern Matching.

parameters.name: Transform Order
parameters.label: Transform Order
parameters.description:
xord -  - Sets the overall transform order for the transformations. The transform order determines the order in which transformations take place. Depending on the order, you can achieve different results using the exact same values. Choose the appropriate order from the menu.

parameters.name: Pivot
parameters.label: Pivot
parameters.description:
p -  - The pivot point for the transformations (not the same as the pivot point in the pivot channels). The pivot point parameters allow you to define the point about which geometry scales and rotates. Altering the pivot point produces different results depending on the transformation performed on the object.	
For example, during a scaling operation, if the pivot point of an object is located at: -1, -1, 0 and you wanted to scale the object by 0.5 (reduce its size by 50%) the object would scale toward the pivot point and appear to slide down and to the left.			
			
In the example above, rotations performed on an object with different pivot points produce very different results.


 px - py - pz -

parameters.name: X
parameters.label: X
parameters.description: px - py - pz -

parameters.name: Uniform Scale
parameters.label: Uniform Scale
parameters.description: scale -  allows you to shrink or enlarge geometry along all three axes simultaneously.

parameters.name: Normals Maintain Length
parameters.label: Normals Maintain Length
parameters.description: vlength - When selected, vector type attributes (i.e. normals, velocity) maintain the same length under transforms. i.e. When geometry is scaled, the normals remain constant in length.

parameters.name: Look At
parameters.label: Look At
parameters.description:
lookat - Allows you to orient your object by naming the object you would like it to , or point to. Once you have designated this object to look at, it will continue to face that object, even if you move it. This is useful if, for instance, you want a camera to follow another object's movements. The  parameter points the object in question at the other object's origin.	
Tip: To designate a centre of interest for the camera that doesn't appear in your scene, create a Null object and disable its display flag. Then Parent the Camera to the newly created Null object, and tell the camera to look at this object using the  parameter. You can direct the attention of the camera by moving the Null object with the Select state. If you want to see both the camera and the Null object, enable the Null object's display flag, and use the Select state in an additional Viewport by clicking one of the icons in the top-right corner of the TouchDesigner window.

 off - No Change. origin - Moves the geometry to the origin 0,0,0. reference - Moves the geometry to a location based on the  Input supplied to this 's second input (ie. Input 1).
